awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated Data-Driven Methodologies to Addressing the Driver Turnover and Shortage Problems in Truckload Transportation
awd_abstract_narration:
In the Truckload transportation industry, high driver turnover is a chronic problem, representing an annual cost of up to $2.8 billion. A primary reason is extended on-road times for drivers, largely a consequence of the point-to-point dispatching most often used in industry. Another related problem that is becoming increasingly important is the driver shortage, estimated to reach 239K in a decade, due to the retirement of the baby-boomer generation, an improving economy, and newly implemented hours-of-service regulations. The  research will comprehensively investigate the driver turnover and shortage problems and address them through a systems-oriented design focus that also includes new proactive operational paradigms. In contrast to existing operational practices to fire-fight individual issues as they arise, a systems approach framework will take into account the perspectives of all stakeholders (drivers, companies, and customers) and involve modeling and analysis of both current and new systems and their operations via descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive analytics. The outcome of this research is expected to make substantial impact in addressing the turnover and shortage problems by providing a systems-oriented framework that incorporates both operational and turnover related costs while improving driver satisfaction with a data-driven collaborative dispatching tool. The research has the potential to significantly reduce an unproductive cost on the order of billions in the industry, and to benefit society by: 1) supporting the driver workforce (and families) with improved health, prosperity, and welfare, 2) unlocking the potential for employment opportunities for new workforce, and 3) reducing costs with improved transportation operations.

The system design and operations can improve driver satisfaction by better accommodating individual preferences for location, schedule regularity, mileage, and other factors while also improving economic measures important to all stakeholders. System development will proceed following a systems-oriented approach that is structured around a framework of three integrated analytical components. These components will be the product of 1) descriptive (designing and collecting field data from groups of drivers and dispatchers to determine the factors affecting truckload operations and turnover as well as their quantified contributions), 2) predictive (applying these data to the design of a new data-driven turnover prediction model in the context of a new collaborative dispatching paradigm), and 3) prescriptive (designing optimum relay and point-to-point networks via an optimization-and-simulation framework that incorporates collaborative dispatching/data-driven turnover prediction and considers operational costs (e.g., empty repositioning) as well as turnover costs obtained by the data-driven turnover prediction model) analytical methods.

por.por_cntn:
Driver turnover and a shortage of drivers in the TruckLoad (TL) transportation industry are two problems that represent significant costs in TL industry. This project has an overarching objective of comprehensively investigating solutions to these problems by introducing new paradigms for system design and operation that are informed by descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive analytics, specifically:

1)      The descriptive analytical thrust involves the collection of field data from TL drivers and dispatchers via a broadly-distributed survey to determine job-related, personal, and social factors that influence the likelihood of a driver quitting their current position, as well as the relative strength of those influences over time.

2)      The predictive thrust uses descriptive data by the surveys to develop prediction models of driver turnover. Our selected model reveals several important takeaways from our analysis of the truck driving turnover problem. In particular, the predictors selected in the model indicate which aspects in the survey are most relevant to driver retention. This information can inform companies of possible changes they could make in their operations so as to lessen their driver turnover rate. We see that drivers are more likely to stay when their company issues them more pre-planned routes, since knowing their schedule ahead of time allows them to make non-work plans. We also see that drivers are less likely to quit if they consider the amount of work assigned to them to be higher, since most drivers are only paid for the miles or time when they are driving. Our model shows that having child care provided by the employer increases retention, but even more so when the driver is married. Our model identified higher driver pay satisfaction as a predictor of retention while that interacts with how a driver feels about how well their dispatcher represents them. A driver feeling a strong affiliation with their company appeared as an indication of retention. Our model also found that some drivers will stay with a company until at least their training costs are repaid.  

3)      The prescriptive thrust includes using input from the survey field data and other system stakeholder perspectives to optimize the relay and point-to-point transportation network design. It also involves integrating the prediction models into a simulation with the optimization tool. The main focus of the project at SMU was this component. The approach facilitates higher driver retention by providing pre-planned routes and higher mileage for better payrates while also simplifying dispatchers’ jobs and create a stronger positive connection between dispatchers and the drivers. Generalized deterministic models and algorithms for relay network design were the first focus of the study. Multiple relay assignments to individual load origins and destinations as well as direct shipment option to optimally integrate relay and point-to-point shipment operations have been incorporated in design. While the resulting problem is challenging, an efficient solution approach based on decomposition methods was devised. In an extensive computational study, we showed the efficacy of the approach and quantified the significant benefits achieved with proposed integrated relay networks over existing systems. In the second stage, we considered uncertainty, represented by scenarios, in the truckload shipment demands and developed efficient algorithms in a stochastic programming context. We extended the common algorithms by devising new cuts that tighten the solution space for this challenging problem and also devised effective ways to jointly use Benders Decomposition and Progressive Hedging approaches. Our simulation study mimics a real operation environment specific to dispatching decisions. We simulate driver-dispatcher collaborative dispatch decisions vs point-to-point dispatcher decisions (as is) on integrated relay and point-to-point only systems and illustrate the benefits of collaborative dispatching on integrated relay networks.

On the application side, as our research addresses workforce retention and shortage in transportation, it can impact the amount of cost that must be absorbed by consumers of various goods that must be transported, it has direct societal consequences. By providing a systems-oriented framework, the bottom line costs to the industry can be minimized, and driver and dispatcher satisfaction can be improved with a data-driven collaborative dispatching tool. The research has the potential to substantially reduce an unproductive cost on the order of billions in the TL industry, and to benefit society by: a) supporting the driver workforce (and families) with improved health, prosperity, and welfare, b) unlocking the potential for employment opportunities for new workforce, and c) reducing costs with improved transportation operations. The results also extend beyond TL operations and support establishing networks for refueling of alternative fuel vehicles such as charging stations for electric vehicles. Our algorithmic approaches are also readily usable in solving hub location and general network design problems which occur widely in practice of logistics. Thus, our results reach outside our problem context to help solve other problems of interest to academics and practitioners.
